author: gaelreinaudi

description.text: A printable model of the good, classic milk bottle.

So long story short I came home for Superbowl, and my father is still a little skeptical about the $3000 Ultimaker 2 purchase that I made about a year ago, so I decided to surprise him with these fancy coins! I found a great design from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43424 and I simply converted it into a vector file and threw a squished cylinder underneath to make it a coin! Then to add an extra flare, I added several pauses in the print to change the filament color and make it look even more awesome!

NOTE I have linked a .gcode file as well so you can see how the pauses are setup to change the filament if you want to. But it is very important that you don't actually use the .gcode file straight into your printer unless you have an Ultimaker 2 and are using PLA. This can seriously damage your printer becasue the settings are different especially things like the buildplate size etc.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

If printing at .1mm layer height (resolution) the pauses are as follows:
(1Unit = 1Layer)
(1Unit = .1mm)

0-20 -> White
20-37 -> Red
37-End -> Black
Give em out to all your friends/family and GO FALCONS!

How it was created

I found a great design from: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:43424 and I simply converted it into a vector file and threw a squished cylinder underneath to make it a coin! Then to add an extra flare, I added several pauses in the print to change the filament color and make it look even more awesome!

If you're a christian then you should love this. The original design was meant to be a necklace but i made it bigger but whoever prints this out can make however big they want it to be. Enjoy my cross ok.

Just a simple sharps container to dispose of used blades from your XACTO knife, utility knife, scalpel, etc. Printed in one piece on my MP Select Mini, it didn't have a problem printing it as it stands out of PLA.

Original model has 3mm walls. Someone thought that was way too thick, so I uploaded a 1.5mm thick model.

Designed in Fusion 360, and I've added the F360 file so you can adjust if needed.

comments.text: In my opinion wall is too thick so it's big waste of filament. I think 1.2-1.5mm would be enough or 2mm for reinforcement. Mine is printing in 3mm each wall, 10 layers on bottom.
comments.author: Nemesis94

comments.text: 3mm walls was intentional. This is a sharps container. You don't want it to be flimsy, you want it to be strong and unable to be punctured. It's also about 3 times the size it needs to be, but again, you don't want it to be flimsy. The Fusion 360 file is available for download, so you can simply change the model up to fit your needs. That's why I added it.
comments.author: Nemesis94

comments.text: Thanks for reply. When im cutting out some of my ABS supports its extremely hard to cut out 1.5 - 2 mm thick pieces. Sometimes it ends up with broken blade. This is why i think 3mm is too much. Anyways extra protection is also good.

description.text:
This is a detector I designed to be able to see if my 1.75mm filament is actually moving. This is especially useful when troubleshooting filament feed issues. You can look at the extruder drive wheel, but that can spin without feeding filament. This uses half of a rubber band that you get on broccoli at the supermarket. It attaches with the bowden connector to my MK8 extruder from Geeetech. I am including the 123Design file so you can modify to fit your situation.

Each segment of the wheel represents about 7mm (7.15 to be exact) of movement.

There is a video of it in operation can be seen here https://youtu.be/JHtcuPsRDpk

Enjoy!

Printer:

Geeetech Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 will do

Infill:

I used 80% to get some strength around the mount

Notes:

Uses m3 nuts, bolt, washers, (2) 3X7X3 bearings and a rubber band.

You will need to drill out the filament guide holes using a 2mm drill bit.

Cut a broccoli rubber band in half lengthwise and stretch around the wheel.

I used a sharpie to highlight the markers on the wheel to promote viability.

The pieces slide together, it is a little tight but it does not require any screws :)
Fits an Arduino Uno with a Seed Studio Ethernet shield. You can fit a little something on the top which is why I have it a little taller than the Uno and shield.

To assemble put the front piece on the ports of the Arduino and Seed Studio Network board, then slide that into the main piece. The fit should be nice and snug. Then you slide on the bottom and try to keep it straight as you slide it on. It should all be very tight and secure, don't be afraid to bang it together to get it all were you need it.

I originally posted this on another account and forgot to but the main piece. The main peice has been added to this one.

author: amjad

title: Disk Brake Shim/Collar for Old Steel Frame

description.text:
I ordered a disk brake conversion kit (just the bracket). Unfortunately it placed the calipers at an undesirable angle and position. I designed and printed a collar/shim that would 1) take up space between the over-sized mounting collar. and 2) provide a straight and vertical position for the collar to grip rather than the angled position of the frame itself.

The end result is a brake caliper that is positioned correctly and was much sturdier than with rubber "sleeves". As an added plus the ABS plastic seems strong and durable enough to remain permanently and it also protects the finish on the frame from the steel collar that attached the bracket to the frame. Notice the B is for the bottom (more narrow tube than at top) and the Line is on top (to get the angle correct).

(I didn't realize and ended up printing mine with only 10% infill! ) So far it seems to be holding up well, however, when it comes time for you to print I recommend using a higher % (Perhaps 50-100%)

I enjoy making old things "new" again and the current standard in MTN bike brakes are disk.....so why not have some fun!?

This project should work for many other older (80-90's) steel frame bicycles as long as the size of the tubing in the rear triangle is of a similar diameter.

description.text:
Customizable Ninja Star (Snowflake?) Hex Nut Fidget Spinner

Check out Customizable Edgy Fidget Star for pointed, beveled edges

update 2017-09-29
Allow for ISO 4032 M10 (16mm) and M12 (18mm) hex nuts along with the old DIN 934 M10 (17mm) and M12 (19mm).
update 2017-04-15:
added even more weight choices: 3/8", M10 hex nuts and 3/8", 1/2", 5/8" loose ball bearings
update 2017-02-05:
allow for choice of nut: 5/16" or M8

  • easy to customize
  • can generate 3 to 6 pointed stars
  • it ranges from around 70 to 100mm
  • easy to print
  • compact
  • requires 1X 608zz (22x7) bearing
  • requires 3-6X 5/16" or M8 hex nuts
  • Smooth filleted edges (sorry, lousy weapon)
  • favorite hardware installation tool: vise grips
  • if weights are loose, soak weight in frame in hot water to tighten
  • See my collection of all of my fidget spinner designs.

comments.text: Sorry your print broke. In your software, there is probably an option to scale your print. You will want to scale in both X and Y, not Z. author: Lucina

description.text:
UPDATE Feb 5/17
So I scaled up the frame and motor mount, but because of that the holes on the motor were too narrow, so I drill and bent them out, gears fit much better, but still need a little tweaking. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_exBGDI-vp0&feature=youtu.be

UPDATE Feb 4/17
Put together, but real tight, going to scale the frame up a little and see if that helps.

What I did was combine the gear sets into 1 model, so you don't have to glue them together, I also had to scale up the spacer a little as the hole was a bit smaller than the gears. I also made a space so not to use a metal one and I also made the nylon washers, I will then drill/file out the gear sets so the spacers will ride smoothly. I also included the 123d file if you would like to play,

just printing now, so hoping it works, will upload pics once it is up and running

as you can see from pics that the gears are printing on top of each other, that is why you need support.

just noticed that 2 of the gear sets came apart, so will have to go back and redraw them.

Hopefully these work

description.text:
I needed a 1:24 Eames chair for a project, but was in a hurry.  I did some quick and dirty modeling based on existing CAD files of the chair, and formatted it for support-less printing.  The overhangs are 5-10 degrees over the optimal 45 in some areas, but printed fine for me on a Rep2.  
Print both pieces without rafts or support material.  There are several manual support contacts you may wish to cut away with an exacto knife.  Glue base and chair together - look up a reference photo online, the base sits farther back than you think.

description.text: I wanted a stable way to mount my extruder to my reprappro mono mendel and this is the 3d iteration of it. Works really well and takes up no space at all.

Printer:

RepRapPro mono mendel

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0,2

Notes:

Print it with flat side down and you shouldn't need any supports, choose any infill you feel comfortable with

Fasten it to the top bars and secure it with 2 zip ties in the groves. Then mount the extruder with 2xM3 screws and nuts.
If you use the standard copper mount for the bowden tube that reprappro uses just drill out the hole enough for it to fit through.
I'm using a quick connect coupler and you should be able to screw that right into the hole.

When you try to add multiple ESC to the BlueROV2, ESC placement gets a little hard.
These ESC Beds will help you to keep your ESC's alligned.

I used 20% infill, 0.3mm PLA. Maybe I will try ABS some other day.
Also, I think Black will look better than magenta, so I will try that as well later.

I decided that instead of money, the winner of our Fantasy Football league should get a trophy. Naturally, I designed it after the Lombardi. However, since it's a Fantasy League Trophy, I figured I'd name it after the greatest Fantasy Coach of all time: Coach Klein from "The Waterboy".

The included .stl files are of the smaller trophy. I ended up designing 2nd and 3rd place trophies that were a little too close in size by comparison, so I used Makerbot Desktop to scale both pieces up until the base was 140mm in the z-direction. Just highlight both models and keep the aspect ratio locked and you should be fine.

Goes with this trophy in the set: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2277771

Wall-mounted remote control holder for Feit Color-Changing String Lights (sold at Costco and other places).

The buttons on the remote will remain accessible when in the holder, so you shouldn't even need to pull it out to use the controls.

No

No

0.16 mm layer height

20% rectilinear infill, archmedian chords top/bottom

Notes:

The mounting tab at the top is reasonably reinforced, but could be somewhat easy to snap off if you print this with a filament that has poor layer adhesion. I prototyped this using super cheap PLA, and it was a concern, despite several design improvements to strengthen that area. I had much better results using PLA from a quality brand, and have used that for my final part.

Update: After hearing about the arm joint getting broken while being played with, I have modified the design to make it stronger. I increased the size of the connecting rods substantially. I adjusted the elbow joint so that it can fold completely. And I enclosed the joints to keep them from sliding up and binding. I have printed the new version and it works quite well as shown in the first two pics. It is the "Little Digger V2" file. My little "Iron Man" from the first video has been testing it. V2 video here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0RYpjmRyl90 I haven't tried scaling this yet. The tolerances would scale as well, so I am not sure how well that would work. End of Update......... I wanted to make a fun toy for my kids for christmas, so I came up with this! This is a pre-assembled excavator called the 'Little Digger'. The arm and bucket have 3 moving joints. The base rotates for Real digging action and the wheels turn. All moving parts have been designed to print in place using the power of the 45 degree angle and a few very small bridges. After getting all of the moving parts worked out, I went to work on the details, adding tread and rims to the wheels, a drive train on the bottom, lights, a cab with a seat and a steering wheel, weights on the back of the turret, teeth on the bucket, hydraulic cylinders on the arms, and of course the 'Little Digger' name down the arm. I created this using tinkercad and have made it public so that others can modify it and make something new. One thing that you can do is change the name on the arm. You can see in my picture that I made one called "Jack's digger" for my son. Or you could take it apart to see how the different parts work. I think this link should work for getting there: https://tinkercad.com/things/eoIsmBEg9vA-little-digger Here's a quick video of my kids playing with a few of them:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RXuIr3-6vQI Print one out for Christmas!

print it :)  I used .2mm layers with 10% fill.  At 100mm/s perimerters and 260 mm/s infill, it took 95 minutes to print.  
Carefully remove it and test the three joints in the arm.  They should already move freely or move with a little bit of wiggling.  Note: the little connectors in the arm joints can be delicate if they are twisted.  
Next take the upper and lower portion of the body in separate hands and twist.  Again, this should move freely to begin with, but may take a little motivation depending on how well your printer works.  
Finally, you need to get the wheels turning.  After my last adjustments to this model, I was able to get them turning by just grabbing them and turning.  If they won't turn for you, try using a pair of pliers to get a better grip.  I wanted to keep the wheel axles tight so they would turn well without binding.  once they are turning, I recommend spraying a little bit of in the cracks around the wheels.  I uses CRC Heavy Duty Silicone.  After the silicone spray is worked in and has dried, they should turn very well.  
If you get carried away and break an arm connector, I have successfully repaired one by melting it back together with a soldering iron.  With that said, my 4, 6 and 8 year olds have played with them a lot without breaking one.  I was the one that got carried away :)  
**** If you find that you need a little looser tolerance, a good way to adjust it is to adjust the size of the object.  The tolerances scale proportionately to the size of the object.

Various sized discs for disc bound notebook systems like Staples Arc, Levenger Circa, and MAMBI Happy Planners. There are four sizes, though the two mediums are very close, the smaller is a Levenger copy, and the larger medium size is a MAMBI Happy Planner copy. The smallest and largest sizes were made from the dimensions of discs from MAMBI's expander rings.

I had a lot of trouble printing these when sliced with Prusa Slic3r, even with supports, the disc would not stick to the bed after a certain point. I didn't try it with a raft. I ended up using Simplify3d with supports and no raft, and they came out beautifully, and the supports came right off of the discs.

remixed_from.title: Knurled Tri-Spinner Fidget Widget / Triple Bearing Spinner

description.text:
I didn't want to waste four of 608zz bearings on a spinner.

As I had some 1/4" hexnuts that didn't have the correct thread to fit a camera tripod, I thought I'd use them as weights, which meant I only need to use one bearing.

So I've modified swholmstead's design to take the smaller hexnuts which don't poke all the way through the holder, and also cleaned up aubenc's knurling2 library to get rid of the calls to polyhedron(triangle) and assign() and some debugging/spacing etc.

Note that to get the best spin use 2 "locks" and put one either side of the bearing as per the photo.

Everything push-fits together, really tightly!

I could not find a brace for the Anet A8 y motor that didnt involve screwing it to the table. Everyone seems to put a giant brace on the front even though it is only holding the idler pulley.

No modifications necessary!

My design anchors the Y axis motor to the threaded rod to reduce motion of the stepper.

Optional: Drill a hole through the rear frame plate in to the new stepper mount and put a screw there to secure the whole thing together.

This is the first thing I've EVER designed and printed.

If i were to do this again I would do:
PLA
layer height: 0.3
no support material (cuz f-it, its just a brace)
Infill 40% 3d honeycomb

The filled version may print quicker but use a little more material.

description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/fo3ifH9YSbV

Small screw top containers with multi start threads. Note that these are very non-standard threads.
There are two sizes and a couple of cap variations.
Another variation is that the smaller container has more and smaller-section threads which I think are a little easier to print.

Made in Diamond Age PLA on an Ultimaker. 0.2mm layer height, 200C.
The cap is neat fit to the container which is good in some ways but does mean the the cap and container need to be 'run in'. Clean the threads as best you can and then 'force' the cap onto the container. Generally I found that I had to hold at least one component with a tool (Jar opener or multi grips) sometimes both. Then work them to and fro a dozen times and all should be well.
The result should be a snug fitting lid with little play or slop.

description.text:
The tires on my sons Walmart Powerwheels car are thin, hollow, and make of plastic. They cracked and split over time (I may have contributed to the cracking by driving the car around myself). This adapter fits the stock drive sprocket to a 10" Pneumatic Harbor Freight wheel and tire ($5.99 as of this posting). The bolts that came with the wheels needed to be replaced with longer ones (they are M8 hex head bolts and needed to be ~30mm).

There is an axel spacer inside of the plastic wheels (12mm axel with a 5/8" wheel bore) that is reused with the HF tires (which luckily also have 5/8" I.D. bearings), but a second one is needed for the other bearing, so I created a model of the spacer as well. When everything is put back together, there is about 3/16" of play between the axel bolt and the tire, but it doesn't present any problems.

This drive sprocket appears to be the same one that came with my car. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:917423

title: Hesine M505 Anet A8 (Prusa i3) X-Mounts incl. 8mm bearing (LM8UU) and belt tensioner

description.text:
This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1718315 and http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:102482

Update 4th Feb.: Sorry, I forgot the Z-endstop mount. Added it now.
Update 18th Feb.: If you are using a auto tramming system, you can use the remixed version without the z-endstop mount: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2118686

I was already using the mounts and want to use the printed bearings. Instead of removing the LM8UU of my old ones and hopefully not damage them - this risk is really high - I decided to print them again, but this time including the bearings already in the print. No gaps, no need of sliding the bearings into the mounts; let the printer do this work for you.

I already exchanged the linear bearings and holders on y-axis and the extruder carriage, they are doing a flawlesly job - so I decided to move on and do the same with the z-axis.

The bearings are on full lenght of the mounts.

UPDATE:
People asked me to change something, therefore there are some changed versions of this thing.
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2238376 - version with z-screw mount moved to the top
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2118686 - version without z-endstop (auto bed leveling)
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2389929 - version without tensioning

just pick what you need or ask me for a change if you have an idea for an optimization

Notes:

printer: Anet A8 (customized)
slicer: Simplify3D
infill: 40% (fast honeycomb)
supports: yes (both)
wall layers: 3
top and bottom layers: 3
speed 100mm/s

At the beginning the bearings are really tight but the rod fits into them. I just used the sharp edge of the rod to remove just a tiny amount of material until the rod moves freely but still stable and without noise throug the bearings.
You are still able to use a drill, but do this on low speeds and check often to not overdo the removal of material.

title: The Echo Box is a complete kit. Fun for learning to code.

description.text:
Echo Box 3D printed Shell parts for our kit.
"Like US" https://www.facebook.com/badbrick Here is a description from our site so you know the parts you'd need if you'd like to make one The Echo Box is a complete kit. Fun for learning to program and play with an Arduino UNO R3. It comes fully assembled and works as a measurement tool. You can write a variety of sketches using the Ultrasonic sensor as well as program the LCD and all the buttons.
It includes:
  • Arduino UNO R3
  • HC-SR04 Ultrasonic sensor, with extension wires.
  • LCD Shield Kit w/ 16x2 Character Display for Arduino Uno R3, with extension wires and pin mounts. We get ours from Adafruit.
  • (2) 9 Volt batteries wired in parallel, with the Arduino Power plug adapter. This is the Power Pack for the Echo Box.
  • A pre loaded basic Distance sensing sketch and the downloadable source code.
    • http://www.badbrick.com/content/badbrick-echo-box-complete-kit

In MakerWare, I modify the "Medium" settings: Quality: Layer Height = 0.18
Infill: 15%
Shells: 2
For the battery base box, Arduino + Sensor Mount base, and top cover. All other defaults are the same. Building the Echo Box. Print all the parts.. Wiring up the Echo Box is pretty easy. The Arduino just sits in the base mount. The HC-SR04 just mounts in the end. I solider on some short solid jumper wires to the Ultrasonic sensor, pins and plug them in. Mount the LCD Shield. When we build these we use the extra long stacking headers. Then we plug in the Ultrasonic sensor in to the pins that are not used. Hopefully that explained it all. Some of the pictures above also show the assembly. If you have any questions or suggestions please feel free to comment.

comments.text: Nice design, I like it a lot.  I have plans to take this and re-work it for the UNO project I am doing :)

description.text:
Update 2/11/17 Added pictures

For most Prusa I3 machines, getting sufficient tension on the belts can be tough. The X Axis belt is the most difficult. This is especially true if you have to take the belt off and try to re-install it, in it's now trimmed form, where you can't seem to get enough purchase on the belt to pull hard enough to get tension anymore. The RepRapGuru I3 (original or V2 with the display) is no exception to this problem. Spring clips are not a good solution, as they add their own artifacts to the print by allowing the belt tension to be variable. What the machine does have is a nice open through-slot on the left side of the X Axis assembly into which we can add our own tension block.

On my prints, I started seeing X-axis shifting, indicating the belt was slipping during the print which ruined several long print jobs. This was my solution.

Instructions

On the left side of the X axis is the belt idler pulley, secured by an M3 bolt and lock nut. We can replace that static bolt with our tension block, allowing us to adjust the tension easily using two M4 screws. You can print this in PLA or ABS, either works well.

Steps:

  1. Print the part supplied here. In addition you'll need:
    (2) M4 bolt x 30MM or larger, then sized to allow for adj w/out too much sticking out.
    (2) M4 nut.
    (1) Strip stainless steel, recommend K&S #87163 available online or at Ace Hardware for less than $2. Cut two 60mm lengths from the strip.
    http://www.acehardware.com/product/index.jsp?productId=106613176
    (1)M3 bolt or 3mm steel rod to act at replacement axle for the idler pulley. Cut and trim this to be exactly the same width as the inside of the slot where the idler pulley screw used to pass through, about 11 mm. Be ready to file this down to size until it's exactly the right length.

  2. On each of the steel strips, drill identical 3mm holes at each end, along the centerline of the strip. See the assembly diagram above. I used a 1/8 inch bit which is just slightly larger than 3mm, and I taped the two strips together to ensure alignment.

  3. Dismount the X axis belt and remove the M3 bolt and lock nut that secure the idler pulley.

  4. Insert the two steel strips into the block, secure them in place by reusing the M3 bolt and locknut from the idler pulley. Insert the two M4 nuts into the nut traps in the block. Insert the M4 screws from the outer face and thread them onto the M4 nuts, but just flush, not all the way through.

  5. Mount the idler pulley onto the exposed ends of the steel strips, passing the M3/3mm replacement axle through the pulley and through the drilled holes in the metal strips.

  6. Insert the now assembled tension block assembly from the outside (leftmost) edge and into the slot. Thread the belt back through the pulley and secure/zip tie to the anchor block on the print head carriage. (you may want to instead pull the belt through the slot in the block and thread it through the pulley, and then pass the belt and block into the slot. Up to you...) Reconnect the belt to the print carriage, taking out as much slack as you can, but no longer needing to really apply force in doing so. That's what the tensioner is for.

  7. Using a screwdriver (or EVEN just finger tight, I've found is sufficient) evenly tighten down on each of the two M4 bolts. This will push the block away from the center of the machine, and tighten the belt. Do so until you have applied enough pressure to lessen the amount of deflection you can get if you try to pinch the belt together. Be reasonable though, and be warned: too much tension can pull the Z Axis smooth rods in towards each other. You could bend them, overload the Z axis bearings and/or the print carriage bearings, or distort your prints in other ways due to this tension and strain. I find that it does not require that much force now that I have the block doing the work for me.

I've supplied the Fusion 360 source file so that you can make adjustments for your application. If you come up with an improvement to it, please share it back! :-)

Notes:

I'm not sure that the stock plastic idler pulley will give you enough clearance on the sides to make this work. I had occasion to change out the stock idler pulley, so I replaced it with an aluminum 20T dual bearing pulley which is what I used when designing the part.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01BTTER04/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&th=1

you could also go toothless, like stock::
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01BTTEQU0/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o02_s00?ie=UTF8&th=1

If you have the stock idler pulley, you could try thinner steel... it should be plenty strong at half the thickness. IE: http://www.acehardware.com/product/index.jsp?productId=106613346

Printer:

RepRapGuru I3 v2

Rafts:

No

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

30%

title: Anet A6 Fan Duct with Light

description.text:
Hey guys. This fan duct will enlighten your prints...
You need:

  • 4x smd led, 1206 package; two led's in series
  • 2x series resistors; I used two 300Ohm resistors in 1206 package
  • some (very) thin insulated wire; I had a 0.25mm (diameter of uncoated wire; 0.5mm with insulation) available
  • soldering iron + solder
  • two connectors (one pin; male+female) or one "two pin connector"; I used this one:
    https://www.conrad.de/de/miniatur-bananenstecker-stecker-gerade-stift-26-mm-schwarz-1-st-730572.html and
    https://www.conrad.de/de/miniatur-laborbuchse-buchse-gerade-stift-26-mm-rot-1-st-731919.html
  • some wire; I used 0.14mm²
  • some tools; I used one slotted screwdriver
  • some endurance; I used my own
  • some time; I didnt have very much

For instruction see pdf I attached.

Anet A6

author: wilper21

title: Flamewheel f450 Anti-Vibration Raspberry Pi 3 and Navio 2 Mount

description.text:
This anti-vibration mount is designed to attach a Raspberry Pi 3 and a Navio 2 to a DJI Flamewheel F450 without any drilling or modification to the base plate. The unique design of the case nullifies the vibration that is generated by the motor and results in increased stability during flight. In addition, the design allows the user to effortlessly remove the Raspberry Pi 3 if needed.

UPDATE* The holes on the naviocase were not extruded far enough so you will need to drill out 2 holes with a drill bit.

Parts needed

-20 x M2.5 10 mm bolts
https://www.amazon.com/Machine-Finish-Phillips-M2-5-0-45-Threaded/dp/B00F33S93E/ref=pd_bxgy_328_2?_encoding=UTF8&pd_rd_i=B00F33S93E&pd_rd_r=9DD8JJYCEEWCDESMG9JQ&pd_rd_w=jS9M2&pd_rd_wg=iFs7P&psc=1&refRID=9DD8JJYCEEWCDESMG9JQ

-Super Glue

-Velcro Strap or Zip tie to attach components together

-8 x Blue Vibration Balls
https://hobbyking.com/en_us/vibration-damping-ball-65g-bag-of-8.html

Directions

1) Insert the dampening balls into the Flamewheel platform (use superglue for increased reliability)
2) Attach the 4 feet to the dampening balls (use superglue for increased reliability)
3) Bolt the feet down so the corners (use loctite for increased reliability) & (be careful there is a front and side to the platform make sure that the front is facing the correct side)
4) Attach the Pi and Navio together using screws that come with the Navio
5) Attached the Pi and Navio to the bottom part of the Pi case using 4 of the screws
6) Attach the Navio lid onto the Navio case
7) Place Pi and Navio on the platform
8) Use velcro strap or zip-tie to hold both parts together

author: thatrandomguy

title: Motor Corner (Direct Drive Mount for Ultimaker)

description.text:
This is a sturdy, simple-to-install, single piece direct drive conversion bracket for the Ultimaker. It mounts to the UM without any modification to the frame. Reduces backlash, simplifies maintainence, puts the motors in a place that is easier to keep cool. Instructions:
  • Loosely mount this to the frame, install the rods and couplers, and then mount the motors.
  • Tighten everything up after confirming that alignments are good.
  • Build a new firmware using Ginge's Marlin Builder and uncheck "Invert Axis: X".
  • Flash this new firmware using Cura
    • BOM:
  • M3 x 20mm hex head cap screws
  • 8mm rod
  • 5mm to 8mm flexible couplers (Many sources - Adafruit, Amazon)
    • Note - you can also use this with the stock rods using ThomasKTN's mod here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:189742 Note - Also worth mentioning... a direct drive conversion does make the machine slightly louder.
Printed with 2mm walls and 30% infill

comments.text: In what orientation should this part be printed?  I guess the two detached pieces are support material, I assume however that more support has to be used as well?
comments.author: 10starjester

comments.text: The two breakaway pieces in the model should be the only support truly necessary. There are a few spots where the overhangs get a tiny bit messy, but all in areas that are concealed when the part is installed.
comments.author: 10starjester

comments.text: Is there a quick explanation on why we use flexible couplings?  Seems like that would cause some backlash in the motion.  I am considering this mod (not using this part) on my Replicator 1 for the Y-Axis motion.
comments.author: dssguy1

comments.text: Flexible couplings are designed to allow lateral and bending movement along the axis but resist any sort of torsional movement... so they shouldn't introduce any meaningful backlash.
comments.author: dssguy1

comments.text: Hey thanks!  I did some research and found the same statements as what you put here.  I am excited to try and mod my Replicator to direct drive using your concept!

print_settings.Notes:: Place upright on print bed with lower edge flat on the ground (so it points upward slightly diagonally). That way it does not need supports, but a brim can help with platform adhesion.

description.text:
GotWay Msuper V3 is an Electric Unicycle with an open wheel design. Consequently, when it gets wet and dirty, it throws everything at your back the road has to offer.

This mudguard is ready for use straight from the printer. Snap it to the rear wheel opening of your Msuper's shell and you're good to go. The outward pressure of the lower clamps will keep it in place until you remove it just as easily.

Edit: someone from California just mentioned, it could be smarter to use ABS instead of PLA for temperature stability. If you're living in warmer areas, I suggest following that advice (needs a heated print bed).

Update Feb 15, 2017: Just uploaded the "Klingon Edition" to address concerns, the mudguard could slide down eventually. Tested successfully on my wheel today and will be tested by others shortly. I suggest to use this one instead.

Update Jul 24, 2017: Added a mudguard version for mounting a German insurance plate. Don't use this unless you absolutely have to! And please add a standard plastic plate holder to cover the sharp edges.

Printer:

Micromake D1

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Place upright on print bed with lower edge flat on the ground (so it points upward slightly diagonally). That way it does not need supports, but a brim can help with platform adhesion.

Position on print bed See a real life test: https://youtu.be/uMWm5L3I1fM Disclaimer

When it comes to 3D modeling, I have no idea, what I'm doing! In fact, this is my very first design.
While I certainly don't want to harm anybody, I cannot guarantee or accept liability for any aspect of this design. It may not fit your wheel, or worst case come off during your ride, block your wheel and break your neck. If you do use my file, you will do so entirely at your own risk!

Made one? Please put your experiences in the comments.

author: wilper21

description.text:
A printhead for the Ultimaker which enables the use of the excellent Printrbot UBIS Ceramic Hotend. This setup is significantly lighter, smaller, and easier to maintain than the stock hotend, and probably any other aftermarket setup as well. Clogging has been nonexistent. Z build height has been increased. Ringing should be reduced. Wobble due to linear bearing play should be reduced. Complex assembly and disassembly routines are a thing of the past. Notes:
  • The UBIS is a thermistor-based design, which will mean adding a 4.7k ohm resistor to R23 on the main board and changing your firmware slightly.
  • There is no provision for a fan mount, because it is intended to work with a crossflow fan as suggested by [foehnsturm on the UM forums]( http://umforum.ultimaker.com/index.php?/topic/2839-the-physics-of-cooling/?p=24211).
  • The hotend clamp is tightened with two #2 x 0.5" plastite screws.

Printed solid in PLA - seems to hold up fine. XT or ABS will surely work great!  
The bearing sleeves have a wall of support material built into them in order to keep things perfectly circular. These will need to be removed with a knife after the print.  
If the fit on the bearings is tight (it should be) warming the printhead slightly over the stove before fitting will enable a tight, semi-permanent fit of the bearings.

remixed_from.title: Otto DIY build your own robot

description.text:
Video: Video

                                              Instrucciones

                                              ENGLISH

1 You have to put the pins that you have puted on the Arduinoin the variables called
PINES. (Lines 80-110) in the Program.

2 You have to calibrate the Servomotors puting the angle thatcorrespond with the angle
that makes that the robot is straight with the varaiables VCA VCB VCD and VCD, try to
change the values it must to be around 90 degrees.
(Lines 130-135) in the Program.

3 Select your tipe of led (Negative or Positive common)in (Line 139) in the Program If it
is Negative put 1 or 2 if it is positive.

4 If you have used the Chinese Arduino Nano you have to instal the drivers.

5 Select in Tools: The Plate (Arduino Nano), The ATheart (ATmega328) and the port, if
you don't know the port you can find in the Administrator of decives in control panel
an example is (COM3).

6 Now we are ready to upload the progran, remember to conect the plate and clic at
upload or Ctrl+U.

  • If you have any question ask me on:
    http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2083489/#comments
    or by email
    [email protected] .

Building materials:
-Pieces 3D
-Arduino Nano Buy in Internet aroud 3$
-Placa de expansion Buy in Internet around 1$
-4 Servos SG90 Buy in internet around 6$
-Bluetooth Module HC-06 Buy in internet aroud 3$
-HC-SR04 Buy in Internet around 1$
-Buzzer Buy in Internet around 1$ (You have to buy 5, because there isn't any page that only sells 1)
-Led RGB Buy in Internet around 1$ (You have to buy 10, because there isn't any page that only sells 1)

This thing was made with Tinkercad by Andrés Fernández Muñoz in Spain.

comments.text: Hola Andrés.  Podrias explicar con un esquema como has hecho las conexiones al arduino y tambien el led. Gracias
comments.author: manurayq

comments.text:
Hola manurayq,
Lo que he hecho con el Led RGB (el mío es de positivo comun), Lo he conectado medianamente unos cables que he soldado a las patillas del Led y en el otro extremo del cable unos pines hembra para conectarlo al Arduino con mayor facilidad. Probablemente puede que no te funcione el Led porque probablemente el tullo sea de negativo comun. En este caso tendrías que cambiar en el programa en las funciones del Led RGB y cambiar donde pone -255 por 255.
Desde mi punto de vista es más práctico que sea de positivo común ya que de este modo no tienes que poner resistencias porque se conecta la patilla del positivo a 3.3v que es lo que yo he hecho.
Luego con el Ultrasonidos le he desoldado los pines macho y le he puesto un cable con pines hembra que van conectados al Arduino.
Una recomendación a la hora de encajarlo: primero sluedas los cables del led, lo encantas, luego pones el Ultrasonidos, después metes la tarjeta de expansión del Arduino nano sin haber puesto el Arduino nano, luego encajas el Arduino en la placa de expansión una vez metida la placa de expansión en la cabeza y por último lo conectas todo.
Espero haberte sido de ayuda.

comments.author: Erutan409

print_settings.Notes:: Supports only needed for the magnet recess on the Ghost.

description.text:
This is a cool magnetized cubicle decoration I put together in Fusion 360, featuring some of my favorite 8-bit characters.

I have designed the characters to take 10mmx3mm magnets and the pellets to take 6mmx3mm magnets. I bought a set of them here: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B01N45JGVO/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o01_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1

The Ghost can be dual extrusion or put together in pieces. I have designed the eye pieces to point in any direction you want.

UD= Up/Down
LR= Left/Right
Fitted= .2mm offset that should pop in with little effort
Unfitted= Raw cutout for dual extrusion or custom fit.

I'm happy to make custom magnet recesses by request.

Printer:

QIDI Tech I

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2

Infill:

15% - 30%

Notes:

Supports only needed for the magnet recess on the Ghost.

comments.text:
Thanks for the thing!
The ghost comes without the hole for the magnet. I've added it, feel free to include the attached file.

description.text:
My Dial Indicator has a different hole pattern than the one by Blink60 and I wanted something I could use on both the UM2 and the UM3. So I designed this one using the same concept which replaces the back panel of the guage.

I also uploaded a STEP file for easier editing.

comments.text:
Don't you know that the right way to mount a dial is to use the 8mm (or 9.5mm for antiques in inch) stem ?
Like here : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2084733
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: I wanted something removable and interchangable. With the Ultimakers a permanent mount is not ideal because of the added weight and the space inside the enclosure is limited. I also had a 1" stem and didn't want to adapt it.  Seeing the idea to replace the back cover seemed like a perfect fit. And there's no reason for it not to work at well. In fact I've used it and it worked out really nicely so far.
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
So to make it interchangeable people will have to adapt your plate to fit the different hole sizes pattern of their dial ?
And if people wants to use their dial for an other purpose ?
Again why do you think dials and jigs manufacturers standardized on a 8mm stem diameter and for some provide an attachment on the dial back ?

author: wilper21

title: Modular Rocket V2.0
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
After the surprising response to my first simple rocket design I started again from square one. This one was designed with 3D printing in mind and meant to be assembled with glue and lock pieces.

Wings are designed to be replaceable in order to make the design more modular. Simply design your own wings and attach them to the bracket portions in the .STL file.

I have tried to be careful of overhangs and regular 3D printer issues such as overhang and clearance tolerances and am hoping with proper placing and slicing this should work amazingly, enjoy guys!

author: Bruster999

print_settings.Notes:: I suggest PLA as its stiffer than ABS, unless you have enclosed your printer or have a heated chamber and they will be exposed to 45c+, then use ABS. Also note if you have even the slightest edge ringing, it will throw the brace off angle, and your printer needs to be trammed well for these to be of good use.

description.text: 90* corner brace for 202 extrusion and M4x8-10mm hardware. The counter sinks are large enough to use any head style you like, panhead, cheesehead or socket cap and washer. I suggest 1.5+mm walls and 30-60% infill. 0.3mm layer height is fine, but 0.15-0.2 will yield a better end result. The inner hypotenuse is 86mm to clear the Y brackets and driveshafts on the bear. 1 version with alignment tabs, 1 without. These will not clear the X carriage, I will update with one that does. Use support for the alignment tabs!

Printer:

Flyingbear P902

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.15-0.3

Infill:

30%+

Notes:

I suggest PLA as its stiffer than ABS, unless you have enclosed your printer or have a heated chamber and they will be exposed to 45c+, then use ABS. Also note if you have even the slightest edge ringing, it will throw the brace off angle, and your printer needs to be trammed well for these to be of good use.
